snippet: After years of delay, the automaker is moving rapidly to try to handle death and injury claims from accidents caused by a faulty ignition switch.
abstract: General Motors announces recall of 8.4 million more vehicles worldwide, most of them for ignition defect similar to flaw that company failed to disclose in other models for more than decade; move comes as compensation expert Kenneth R Feinberg unveils plan to pay victims of accidents involving vehicles already recalled, promising swift payments for people who were critically injured and more than $1 million for families of those who died.

byline.contributor: Danielle Ivory, Aaron M. Kessler and Christopher Jensen contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: After years of delay, the automaker is moving rapidly to try to handle death and injury claims from accidents caused by a faulty ignition switch.

headline.main: As Recalls Expand, G.M. Offers Plan for Victims of Faulty Ignition Switch
headline.print_headline: As G.M. Unveils Its Payout Plan, Recalls Expand
